Award.AwardTitle: Modeling and Observational Study of Decadal El Nino-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) Modulation and Tropical Pacific Decadal Variability
Award.AbstractNarration:
The El Nino-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) phenomenon provides an important source of climate predictability on interannual time scales. The research aims for mechanistic understanding of the processes important to the decadal modulation of ENSO and tropical Pacific decadal variability through model experiments and observational analysis. It is hypothesized that the low frequency components of stochastic atmospheric variability in the North and South Pacific, namely, the North Pacific Oscillation (NPO) and Pacific-South American (PSA) variability, independently drive tropical Pacific decadal variability. Furthermore the tropical Pacific decadal variability driven by NPO interacts with ENSO and modulates its amplitude through meridional displacement of the mean intertropical convergence zone (ITCZ). The PSA variability, on the other hand, appears to drive ENSO-like decadal variability associated with the Pacific Decadal Oscillation (PDO), affecting precipitation in the South Pacific convergence zone (SPCZ).

These hypotheses will be tested through detailed analysis of climate and atmospheric model experiments. The model results will also be validated with observational analysis of various instrumental data and paleoclimate proxy records for the past 100-200 years. The observational analysis will show if the ITCZ and SPCZ vary independently on decadal-interdecadal time scales and how their decadal variability is associated with the decadal ENSO modulation. The results obtained from the project will not only shed light on the nature of tropical Pacific climate variability but also provide guidance in understanding the uncertainty of future ENSO behavior and in interpreting paleoclimate proxy records of ENSO.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project funded by National Science Foundation focused on characterizing and understanding tropical Pacific climate variability, which strongly affect weather patterns around the world, including the US. Sea surface temperatures (SSTs) in the equatorial Pacific Ocean become warmer (El Niño) or colder (La Niña) than normal on intervals of 3-8 years. The amplitude of this so-called El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) phenomenon is known to vary from decade to decade in association with changes in the time mean state of the tropical Pacific Ocean. Mechanisms of this decadal ENSO modulation are poorly understood, partly due to lack of long, reliable observations. Recent advances in climate models and computing power allow us to conduct multi century-millennium simulations of climate models that reproduce important features of tropical Pacific climate. The project explored the mechanisms of decadal ENSO modulation through detailed analyses of such long climate model simulations.

The analyses of climate model simulations indicate that not only the amplitude but also various other characteristics of ENSO systematically modulate on decadal time scales. For example, El Niño events become more frequent and persistent during decades when the tropical Pacific Ocean is slightly warmer than normal. On the other hand, both El Niño and La Niña become stronger during decades when the eastern tropical Pacific is warmer than normal and the western tropical Pacific is colder than normal. When ENSO becomes stronger, La Niña events tend to last longer. These characteristics of ENSO modulation are not inconsistent with analyses of limited observational data.

Do decadal changes in the tropical Pacific Ocean cause changes in ENSO? Or is it the other way around? To understand the causality of ENSO modulation and decadal variability of the tropical Pacific Ocean, the project analyzed hierarchical climate model simulations in which the atmosphere is coupled to the ocean with varying degree. When the impact of atmospheric winds on ocean currents is disabled in the model, pronounced interannual variability of equatorial Pacific SSTs associated with ENSO disappears because the dynamical coupling of the equatorial ocean and atmosphere is the fundamental mechanism of ENSO. Decadal variability of the tropical Pacific Ocean, however, continues to exist in this simulation. Further analysis suggest that this decadal variability of the tropical Pacific Ocean is likely induced by atmospheric wind variability over the South Pacific. This result suggests that decadal changes in the tropical Pacific Ocean is likely to cause changes in ENSO while ENSO changes may in turn enhance changes in the background state. Climate model experiments were conducted to confirm this hypothesis.

The project significantly expanded previous research of decadal ENSO modulation that focused mostly on the ENSO amplitude. The project also suggested an important role of the South Pacific atmospheric circulation in decadal variability of the tropical Pacific Ocean and ENSO modulation, which calls for the enhancement of observational networks over the South Pacific. 

The project also had significant broader impacts outside the discipline of climate dynamics. The ENSO phenomenon is the largest source of climate variability and causes significant socioeconomic impacts around the world, including water resources, agriculture, fisheries, sea level, and wildfire hazard. Understanding how the ENSO modulates on decadal time scales is critical to improve predictions of these climatic impacts. The project also contributed to the development of human resource in science by supporting an early-career female scientist and training two female PhD students. Finally, the project helped to expand the climate research program at the University of Texas at Austin Institute for Geophysics.
